Description: Wheel-made pottery sanctuary lamp, with a central tube and nine nozzles. Traces of a black slip (eroded) and soot on nozzles. Brown fabric with gray core.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Dr David George Hogarth
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by Egyptian Museum, Cairo. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Probably Nile silt, though fabric not clear as only inspected from photographs. Appears to be an Egyptian copy of a Greek ‘sanctuary lamp’. Parallels from Athens, Naukratis and Salamis (Bailey 1975, Q37.bis, Q152, Q494; Howland 1958, no.371, dated early 3rd century BC). Similar examples have been found in cemetery contexts, so label of sanctuary lamp may be misleading in this case. Howland, R.H. 1958. The Athenian Agora, IV, Greek lamps and their survivals. Princeton.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (KA.23) (Phase 3)
